qas.question: What keeps being debated in Germany?
What does Gunlick remark that the German System of  dual federalism requires strong Länder to have other than the capacity to implement legislation?

answers.text: pay for it from own source revenues

qas.question: How many proposals have failed so far?
What keeps being debated in America?

plausible_answers.text: make coordination among them and with the federation more complicated

qas.question: What happens if there are too many regional governments?
What has failed so far in America?

plausible_answers.text: there are significant differences among the American states

qas.question: Why are there calls for territorial changes?
What was Arthur B. Gunlicks not in favor of?

plausible_answers.text: the German system of dual federalism requires strong Länder

qas.question: What is one argument for increasing the number of Lander?
What changes have been successfully implemented in Germany?

context: A new <a0_0><b3_0><b8_0>delimitation of the federal territory<b8_0/><b3_0/><a0_0/> keeps being debated in Germany, though "Some scholars note that <b9_0>there are significant differences among the American states<b9_0/> and regional governments in other federations without serious calls for territorial changes ...", as political scientist Arthur B. Gunlicks remarks. He summarizes the main arguments for <b10_0>boundary reform<b10_0/> in Germany: "... <b11_0>the German system of dual federalism requires <b7_0>strong Länder<b11_0/><b7_0/> that have the administrative and fiscal capacity to implement legislation and <a1_0>pay for it from own source revenues<a1_0/>. Too many Länder also <b4_0>make coordination among them and with the federation more complicated<b4_0/> ...". But <a2_0><b5_0>several<a2_0/> proposals<b5_0/> have failed so far; <b12_0>territorial reform<b12_0/> remains <b6_0>a controversial topic<b6_0/> in German politics and public perception.
